awd_titl_txt: Infinite Dimensional Lie algebras, Quantum Groups and their Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The concept behind proposed research can be characterized as the study of mathematical aspects of symmetry properties in quantum theory and statistical mechanics. The first part of the project is focused on the objects which appear in the analysis of models of quantum field theory in two-dimensional space time with special conditions on the boundary. In the second part the PI will study the reasons why some mechanical systems can be solved exactly analytically and the symmetry arguments that go with this. The third and the fifth parts are related to questions involving statistical aspects of symmetry. The fourth part of the project is to connect quantum mechanics and a special two dimensional quantum field theory. This part is expected to bring new insight into now relatively the old subject of quantum mechanics.

In the first part of the project the PI proposes to investigate Harish-Chandra series in a broad setting of finite dimensional simple Lie groups, affine Lie groups and their quantum counterparts. The second part can be viewed as a classical counterpart of the first part. It appears that a classical Hamiltonian counterpart of Harish-Chandra theory is a superintegrable system. The third and the fifth parts outline projects at the interface of representation theory and statistical mechanics. One of the specific directions here is the study of of limit shapes in integrable models of statistical mechanics. The fourth part of the project is built of prior results of the PI and the main goal is to give a description of a full semiclassical asymptotic of eigenfunctions of integrable systems in terms of Feynman diagrams for the corresponding Poisson sigma model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The first objective of the proposal was to study vector valued Harish-Chandra (HC) series and corresponding affine and quantum analogs. In the split case such series are constructed in the a joint paper with J. Stokman. These results were extended further in two other papers (with J. Stokman and H. De Clercq)
The second main objective was to study superintegrable systems in Hamiltonian mechanics, in particular, the construction of spin Calogero-Moser type systems for all symmetric spaces and the proof of their suprintegrability. The PI gave a comprehensive analysis of such systems on homogeneous spaces and for N-spin Calogero-Moser systems. The results are published in two papers. 
The third objective was to the study of statistics of irreducible components in "large" representations of "large" groups. The PI continued the work in this direction initiated with O. Postnova. The asymptotic of the character distribution for parameters on the walls of Weyl chambers is derived. The distribution of tilting modules for large tensor powers of fundamental representations of quantum sl(2) at roots of unity is described. 
The fourth objective was to construct full semiclassical expansion (in all orders) of transition amplitudes between bases of eigenvectors of two transversal semiclassical integrable systems in terms of Feynman diagrams for the Poisson sigma-model. The work in this direction is continued. The PI gave a series of lectures on this subject in Erwin Schroedinger Institute in 2020.
The last objective was to study limit shapes in statistical mechanics. In the paper with David Keating and Ananth Sridhar the integrability of Limit Shapes for the inhomogeneous Six Vertex Model was established.  Two point correlation functions for the 6-vertex model were computed numerically with Pavel Belov where the existence of a mesoscopic scaling limit was conjectured for the first time.
